qas.question: What branch of linguistics is phonology distinguished from?
What kind of linguistics is phonetics considered to be a part of?
Phonology is generally considered a part of the theoretical side of what discipline?
When was the phonome's modern concept developed?
What subfield of modern phonology other than phsycholinguistics crosses over with phonetics?
What branch of linguistics is laboratory distinguished from?
What kind of linguistics is laboratory considered to be a part of?
Laboratory is generally considered a part of the theoretical side of what discipline?
When was the laboratory's modern concept developed?
What subfield of modern phonology other than phsycholinguistics crosses over with laboratory?

context: Phonology is often distinguished from <a0_0><b5_0>phonetics<b5_0/><a0_0/>. While phonetics concerns the physical production, acoustic transmission and perception of the sounds of speech, phonology describes the way sounds function within a given language or across languages to encode meaning. For many linguists, phonetics belongs to <a1_0><b6_0>descriptive<b6_0/><a1_0/> <b7_0>linguistics<b7_0/>, and phonology to theoretical <a2_0>linguistics<a2_0/>, although establishing the phonological system of a language is necessarily an application of theoretical principles to analysis of phonetic evidence. Note that this distinction was not always made, particularly before the development of the modern concept of the phoneme in the <a3_0><b8_0>mid 20th century<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Some subfields of modern phonology have a crossover with phonetics in descriptive disciplines such as psycholinguistics and <a4_0><b9_0>speech perception<b9_0/><a4_0/>, resulting in specific areas like articulatory phonology or laboratory phonology.
